author: freehouse_throwaway
body:
i mean that'll require a sizable capital tie-up given you can only really do cash secured puts in most (all?) IRA

just indexes and select equities with high premium like NVDA/AMD/MU (kind of high). you should be selling puts on stuff you're okay with bag holding. you can usually get like almost 2% return on a weekly basis from NVDA/AMD alone - if i remember right.

i should clarify, the 70% (prob closer to 80%) gain arent really all from just selling puts  - prob half of it are from leaps on DIS/AAPL/QQQ/SPY/MSFT as well. if i remember right, i only utilized about the 30-40% of the capital in the tax-advantaged accounts to buy/sell options. that and covered calls.

rest of the 70% is just in boring o' total market index funds etc. zero bonds. fuck bonds we're still a relatively young family and we're in a non-stop QE bull market.

author: faithnoless
body:
I hope your teacher gives you the option of investing in more than one stock!  If I had that sort of cash for real, I'd put $5 into each of 20 different stocks.  If this started a week ago and you chose Tesla, then you'd be a happy camper right now!  But I think it'll pull back quite a bit after some hype wears off.  Stocks that shoot up very high and very quick like that always pull back, sometimes a lot.

The only thing I don't like about this project is how investing shouldn't be boiled down to weeks, but I guess that's all the time you have to work with in a school.  So my advice:  if you do this for real when you're older, think about 8 YEARS instead of just weeks or months!

Still reading, or getting bored yet?  Here are some picks:  Amazon, Mastercard or Visa, Shopify, The Trade Desk, Adobe, Cognex, MongoDB, Match Group, Okta, Stitch Fix, Square, Twilio, Zscaler, Zoom Video Communications, MercadoLibre, Wix, Roku, Nvidia, Netflix, Micron Technology.  Given your short time frame, some of these should give you a good boost during that time - unless the market has a bit of a correction, which it might because it's been "hot" lately.  Pick some, pick all, whatever your teacher lets you do.  Hope this helps!

Fairly new trader looking for advice

I’m pretty new to trading bought $3800 CAD worth of shares  between early 2018 and October 2018 in Canadian cannabis companies (Aurora, alefia,TGOD, Micron waste, and hexo) all of them are down right now lol. I don’t plan to sell for a couple years until the cannabis business is running properly. I have about 10k CAD to invest but not too sure what to do . Any advice would be appreciated !

I’m 21 currently in school and work part time at the moment. I’m trying to save as much money from investing as possible. I don’t mind taking risks and would like to be a bit aggressive in my investing approach. My  debt currently is my student loans (11k) and my car (6k).

author: ChompySnack
body: Small price stocks are hard to wheel. You need a very liquid options market or the spread will make it much less profitable. Also $2k is not nearly enough unless you want to hold a single risky and downtrodden stock that don’t generate much premium. With that little an amount you also won’t be able to diversify. It’s best not to hold more than 5-10% of your account in any one stock. If you can get margin on your account, skip the put phase and buy the stock and sell an ITM (I like around 70 delta) call. That’s the same trade as a short put but you can leverage 4x usually. You can find stocks that can average between 0.5-1.0% a week. Going out farther than one week reduces risk and return. Some of my go-to lower price stocks are SFIX, MU, SNAP, TWTR, BAC, CIEN, CSCO, LK, MU, T, WDC, and XLNX. Beware of earnings!

author: FreakingOutTheNGHBRD
body:
Anytime is good. MU is a cyclical stock (look up micron cyclical to see why) so just buy 100 shares and sell a covered call every month with a strike at least 50 cents above your average cost. If the stock slips too much and you can't get a decent premium selling a strike above your average cost, weigh your previous premium gains against that and lower your strike so that if the shares were called away, you wouldnt have lost money all things considered.

my average cost was like 49 for a while (its lower now) and the stock went down to the low 40's. I couldn't sell a $50 strike for more than like 60 bucks. But I had already made 6k selling calls on MU. So I said, let me sell a 45 call then for three months out and get a 900 premium. If it does hit 45, ill lose money, but not more than I've made in total selling calls against my shit.

that's just the way i think of it. but yeah i would just buy now while its below 60

author: freehouse_throwaway
body:
Ok day from my [dip-buying](https://www.reddit.com/r/wallstreetbets/comments/ewuvf8/weekend_discussion_thread_january_31_february_2/fg4jqk8/) on Fri:

* Dump V $202.5c for good gains. 30% on them (avg $1.4, out at $2)
* NVDA basically got out early before theta crushed it. avg 1.5, out at 1.65
* AIMT was only able to offload one fucking contract at open. RIP rest.
* ATVI continues to fuck me. Bought more.
* PTON looking good so far. Diamond hands.
* Closed out all my SPCE 2/21 $20c on this crazy ass close. Avg of .7 out at ~$1.20

honestly should have just sold puts with AIMT but didnt want to tie up capital.

MU is green today but got theta fucked. sigh. need this back to $55c fast or I'm fucked on these.
